section.title: Updating a System Repository
section.para: To keep your system content current, you will need to run Deploy on a regular basis. Each time Deploy runs, it checks for changes in the definition or in input data - such as new packages available from an input repository - and refreshes the repository as necessary.

If Deploy finds updated packages, it refreshes the to contain just the current set of packages. Specifically, when Deploy determines that packages have changed, it calculates the list of packages needed to satisfy repository requirements, and then adds and removes packages as necessary to bring the repository into conformance with the list. This behavior allows the to rely on packages in the repository as a master list of packages to be installed on client machines.
To update your repository, you use the same command as you used to initially build it, for example:
You can automate repository updates using cron. The following example shows a shell script that updates the web-server repository.

informalexample.programlisting:
#!/bin/sh DEF_DIR=/root/definitions PARAMS="\ $DEF_DIR/web-server.definition \ "
for params in $PARAMS; do deploy $params done

section.para: You can extend this script to update additional repositories by adding lines to the PARAMS variable. To run the script on a nightly basis, save it to a file (e.g. nightly_build.sh), copy the file to the /etc/cron.daily folder, and make it executable (e.g. by using the command chmod +x /etc/cron.daily/nightly_build.sh).
